body:
Since the mass uptake of smartphones and tablets, there has been a change in how people access and consume content. This is reflected in changing expectations: Users want to access the same content on all their devices, rather than accepting a stripped down 'mobile version.'

As a result, there has been a gradual move away from fixed layouts designed for a set screen size and resolution. Instead, content creators and providers are turning to flexible, dynamic layouts that work on all devices, distributing rich content to mobile devices as well as desktops. This approach is known as responsive web design (RWD) because the layout responds to the device’s view port size and browser.

The flexibility offered by responsive design benefits both the developer and the user. Rather than offering multiple versions of a site or application, only one fully featured site needs to be developed.
title: What is responsive design?

body: A site designed with RWD adapts the layout to the viewing environment by using fluid, proportion-based grids, flexible images,and CSS3 media queries (an extension of the @media rule), in the following ways:
title: How does RWD work?
instruction: Select the arrows to find out more.
mobileInstruction: Select the arrows to find out more.

_items.title: Fluid grid
_items.body: The fluid grid concept calls for page element sizing to be in relative units like percentages, rather than absolute units like pixels or points.

_items.title: Flexible images
_items.body: Flexible images are also sized in relative units, so as to prevent them from displaying outside their containing element.

_items.title: Media queries
_items.body: Media queries allow the page to use different CSS style rules based on characteristics of the device the site is being displayed on, most commonly the width of the browser.

body: A responsive web site adapts itself to the screen resolution, and you see screen elements re-arrange as the browser resolution changes.

body: This is why you need to consider RWD while creating e-learning modules:
displayTitle: Why is RWD important for e-learning?
title: Why is RWD important for e-learning?
instruction: Select the headings to find out more.

_items.title: Increasing mobile usage
_items.body: Mobile usage continues to grow, and more and more learners take training from mobile devices. You need to be able to provide a better experience with viewing and interacting with your course.

_items.title: Easier to update
_items.body: Courses developed using responsive frameworks can be updated easily. There is no worry about updating for different publishing options to be compatible with different browsers, devices, technology, operating systems, and screen sizes.

_items.title: Future-proofing online trainings
_items.body: Good responsive web design is a solution for the future as well. As technology continues to change, we see different devices and browsers, and only responsive design keeps up with these.

Adapt is an extensible HTML5 e-learning framework for developers.

Adapt Framework creates HTML5 e-learning courses. These may be delivered with a web server or a SCORM compliant learning management system. The Adapt framework powers the Adapt authoring tool, an easy to use design tool for creating Adapt courses.
